lines.text:
[reading Pollyanna's locket]
When you look for the bad in mankind, expecting to find it, you surely will. - Abraham Lincoln.
He was President.
Yes, I know... but I've never heard *that* before.

[after Jimmy Bean jumps out of the tree and scares her]
Why don't you come out of the front door like normal people?
They won't let us. I can come out anytime I want with my tree.
You could also fall and hurt yourself badly. You shouldn't play in trees.
That's stupid. Don't you believe in God?

[offended]
Of course I do! But what's that got to do with it?
He grew it there, didn't He? So I can climb it anytime I want.
You're much too young to go around discussing things you don't know anything about.
[coolly walks away]

[chasing after her]
He did too! Why else would it be there?
Shows you're very juvenile.
You aren't so much, you girl! 'Sides, I'm something you can't be. I'm an orphan.

[exaggerated patience]
Go away from me, please, little boy.

[mimicking her]
Go away from please, little boy!

[finally losing her cool]
What is it you want?

[suddenly all smiles]
I wanna go fishin'! You wanna come along?
I'm your Aunt Polly.
How do you do?
This is the pastor of our church, Reverend Ford.
How do you do? I can see there's a family resemblance.
She looks very much like her mother.
Mother always used to say I looked like you!
Would you be good enough to stand erect and in a proper manner, please? And where in the world did you get that dress?
It came in the missionary barrels.
Missionary barrels?
Yes, her father was a minister. As a matter of fact, he was a missionary in the British West Indies.

[exploring her Aunt Polly's house]
Who lives in all these?
There's no one lives in them. They're just *there*.
What for?
That's what being wealthy is. You sure are a question-asker, aren't you?
Stuffy in here. Not much of a room, is it?
But it's my own, anyway. I'm glad of that. Ooh, and the bed's soft! And it's got a lovely window.
[Pollyanna looks out the window and sees Nancy embracing a man]
Who's that man down there with Nancy?
None of your business. Just be sure you're dressed in time for dinner. Think she'd do better than this for her own niece.

[finding Reverend Ford, head bowed, on his knees in prayer]
Paul? Are you alright?
Nobody owns a church, no one.
My father used to say that if we ever had the money you have, we would eat steak and ice cream three times everyday!
Aunt Polly? Do you ever have steak and ice cream?
Are you complaining about the food?
Oh, no, it's delicious! I just wondered. My father always used to say that if we ever had the money you have, we'd have steak and ice cream three times every day!
Pollyanna, I think we ought to get one thing straight right now. I don't want you constantly quoting what your father used to say. Do I make myself clear?
Mm-hm.
You go get the luggage. Be careful with the fresh eggs. They're wrapped in paper.
Yes, dear.
Oh, and Ben?
Yes, dear?
I want you to write a letter to the president of this railway. There were men smoking in the parlor car. Disgraceful! I've taken his number.
Yes, dear.
Now, about the sermon, Reverend.
Yes. The transity of life. That fleeting vapor. It appeareth, and it vanisheth. James, the New Testament. You want me to weave a theme of this into my ser...
Well, let me tell you what my father said to Reverend Moffat.
Yes, what did he say?
He said you only have the congregation for one short hour a week. And there are six long days of mischeif for them before you get them again.
Ah! I see your point. Strike hard on Sunday the excessiveness of God's wrath and hope they carry it with them a few days into the week!
Exactly what I mean.
I'm sorry about the dress, Aunt Polly. My Father said it was a size too big, but that I should be glad it wasn't a pair of boy's trousers.
Well, that's hardly anything to be glad about.
Well, my father always used to say...
Yes, well, never mind what your father used to say. Pollyanna, this is going to be your new home now, and I hope you'll be very happy with me. Nancy will show you to your room.
I'm very glad you sent for me, Aunt Polly. Your home is very lovely.
Thank you.
It must make you awfully glad.
Glad?
That you're so very rich!
[Reverend Ford starts to cough. Nancy takes Pollyanna out of the room]
Honestly!
Did I say something wrong?
Well, let's just say there are about sixty-eleven things you could've said besides that!
I run a clean kitchen! No shenanigans in here, and you clean up after yourself!

[petting her aunt's dog]
Hello! What's his name, please?
*His* name happens to be Elizabeth!
Oh, you're a girl! You're lovely.
Leave her alone and come along.
How - how do I address you, please?
Just call me Nancy, same as everyone else.
Nancy, I thought I made myself clear about gentlemen callers.
Mam?
Don't pretend you don't understand me. I saw you and George Dodds out in the summer house.
George has been every inch a gentleman with me!
We won't discuss it! If you want to remain on my staff, I don't want you to see him any longer.
Pollyanna, I think we should talk about you and your position in this community. Do you know why it's called Harrington Town?
Mother said it was named after my grandfather.
That's right. And everyone in this town looks to us to set a good example. In how we conduct ourselves, in our duties and manners, in what we think and even what we say.
[Angelica rolls her eyes in disgust]
So we must always try to be good examples to everyone in everything we do. Is that clear?
Yes, Aunt Polly.
Just remember our family position and conduct yourself properly. And modestly.
Oh, you mean before? I understand that now. I'll never say that again!
You understand what?
About the money. I'm not supposed to be glad we're so very rich. Huh?
Well, uh, I think it's time for you to get ready for bed, young lady.
That dress is disgraceful. Tomorrow we'll go into town and get you some decent clothes.

[incredulous]
Store-bought?
Why, of course. Where else would we get them?
Out an actual store? *New* clothes?
You're a Harrington now. I want you to look like one.
Oh, Pollyanna, will you please get into the car? We've simply got to get home!
In a rush?
[George grabs Nancy and kisses her. Nancy pushes him away]
Oh! George, stop it! Oh, Pollyanna, you don't know my cousin Fred, do you?
Your cousin Fred?
This is Miss Harrington's niece.

[pointedly]
The one who's come to live with her!

[realizing]
Oh! Oh, that one! Well, hello, Pollyanna, how are you?
Fine, thank you.
Well, how 'bout this? Running into you after... what's it been, six years? Say, how's your ma and pa?
Why, they're just fine.
You know, Pollyanna, I don't take too much to relatives, but this girl was always just like a sister to me. I tell you, I love, love this cousin.
[He kisses Nancy again]
Will you cut it out?
How'd you like to go down the street and get a great big dish of ice cream, my treat? Oh, no, that's a rotten idea. She probably hates the stuff.
Probably.
Who, me? Oh, no, I love it!
No kidding? How'd you ever develop a taste for that awful stuff?
Oh, no, really! I really do love it!
I know the perfect place. Come on, girls, follow old Cousin Fred to the land of strawberry frappe. Unless you'd rather go down the street and have a beer?
You're funny.
I think it might be better if you didn't mention the ice cream to your aunt.
My father taught me never to tell a lie.
Oh, Pollyanna, it wouldn't be telling a lie. But there's no reason to bring up the subject if it isn't mentioned. About Cousin Fred, I mean.
I like your Cousin Fred. Very much.
Oh, he's all right, I guess.
He's very handsome, and he has a nice smile. But there's something... I don't know... funny about him.

[suddenly defensive]
What do you mean, funny?
I know what it is! It's his name. He doesn't look at all like a Fred!
What?
He looks more like a George to me!

[finding Pollyanna hidden behind a plant]
Hello. Is this the town meeting?
Oh, no. It's in there. In the conservatory, for heaven's sake.
Oh. Are you one of the Ladies Aide?
Oh, no. I'm just a child. I'm not even supposed to *be* here! Sh!
What's your name?
Pollyanna Whittier. That's my aunt over there, the pretty one. This is her house, and I live with her.
Sh!
Sh!
If we could all just be a little more quiet, cooperative, orderly please. If we could all just stop shouting and cooperate, I'm sure...
There is nothing wrong with that building! All it needs is new plumbing.
Today the plumbing, tomorrow the roof, and the Lord knows what - excuse me, Reverend - and who knows what's going to happen next!
You were very happy when my father donated the building to the town.
Oh, for pete's sake, Polly Harrington, listen to reason! It's a dilapidated old relic! The dining hall, the dispensary. Even my nephew Dr. Chilton there, he noticed that. Ed, tell them what you said.
I don't think I ought to say anything.
No, no, now, tell them what you said. I want them to hear it.
Well, I got a pretty good look at the dispensary when I fixed Mr. Geary's arm, and I imagined it seemed a little inadequate for thirty-two children.
There, now you've heard it.
We all thank you for your interest, Edmond, but it's an equipment problem. We're talking about Harrington House, which is a landmark in this town, and I intend to see that it stays that way.
It would cost more to fix that dilapidated old wreck than it would to put up a new one!

It won't cost this town one cent! My father donated the building to the town, and I will stand the cost of the pipes or the plumbing or whatever it is that's necessary. It's my duty, and I will not shirk it.
And I suppose there's not one person here who has the gumption to stand up and say what you think? Is there? What about you, Reverend?
No, no, I never take sides in these matters.
If you ask me, Reverend Ford should've taken sides with Mayor Warren. He had the chance, and what did he do? Said he never takes sides in these matters.
Oh, stop sticking your nose into their business and get this sherbert out there!
We're out of spoons.
Well, wash some up! Don't stand there belly-achin' to me about it!
You're in a fine mood, aren't you?
Pollyanna, I thought you could use this for your room.
Oh, thank you, Nancy! Oh, it's gorgeous!
Well, thanks for not spilling the beans about you-know-who.
About Cousin Fred, you mean?
Mm-hm. Isn't he handsome?
I knew it all the time!
You did? How did you know?
Oh, sure, it was easy. I saw you holding hands under the t...
If you two ladies have got nothing better to do than sit there gosippin' and snickerin'...
Oh, we're just talking, Tillie!
Well, talk on your own time. This sherbert is turning to mush.
Nancy, you know that man?
What man?
The man at the train station. The one who was just here. Well, what was he to Aunt Polly?
Oh. You might say they used to be friends. Sort of.
Do you think he's gonna marry Aunt Polly?
Who's gonna marry her?
She means Dr. Chilton.
Fat chance of that! Who'd want to marry old pickle-faced Harrington?
Nancy, are you and George gonna get married?
We hope to, someday.
Oh, I am glad. I think everyone should be married. And maybe, when you do get married, Aunt Polly will see how happy it makes you, she'll be very glad to get married herself, then.
Glad this, glad that. Do you have to be glad about everything? What's the matter with you, anyway?
Oh, lay off her, Angie. She's not hurting you.
The way she goes on...
That's enough! You heard her. Stop picking on the girl. Take that sherbert out and serve it the way you should.
We looked for the good in them, and we found it, didn't we?

[after reading note from Polly]
Oh my God, what have I done? What have I done?
Death comes unexpectedly!
Brimstone and Damnation on top of ham and eggs.
Miss Pollyanna?
Yes? Aunt Polly?
No, I'm Nancy. I work for your aunt and I came here to fetch you.
Oh. How do you do?
This is Thomas, the gardener.
How do you do?
Hello, young lady.
Oh, Thomas will take your luggage for you. Put it in the back seat. Oh, good afternoon, Mrs. Tarbell.
Is that Jenny Harrington's child?
Yes, it is.
Doesn't look a thing like any of the Harringtons. What's your name, girl?
[Pollyanna says nothing]
Speak up!
Pollyanna Whittier, mam.
You're a very fortunate little girl. Most children who have lost their parents would be sent to an orphange.
[Pollyanna looks away]
You know that, don't you?
Yes, mam.
Thank your lucky stars for a good woman such as your aunt taking you in.
